item.text: ORDER OF PROCEDURE - Mr. Cannon asked unanimous consent that the proceedings by which the Yeas and Nays were ordered on the adoption of H. Con. Res. 454 be vacated, to the end that H. Con. Res. 454 be laid on the table. Agreed to without objection.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on H. Con. Res 454 the Chair put the question on adoption of the concurrent resolution and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Frank (MA) demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings on adoption of the concurrent resolution until later in the legislative day.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Con. Res. 454.

summary.text:
Provides for an adjournment of the House of Representatives from July 27 or 28, 2006, until September 6, 2006 (or until another time of reassembly under this concurrent resolution), and a recess or an adjournment of the Senate from August 3, 4, or 5, 2006, until September 5, 2006 (or until another time of reassembly).

Authorizes the Speaker of the House and the Majority Leader of the Senate, or their respective designees, acting jointly after consultation with the Minority Leaders of the House and of the Senate, to notify the Members of the House and the Senate, respectively, to reassemble at such place and time as they may designate whenever, in their opinion, the public interest shall warrant it.

bill.title: Providing for an adjournment or recess of the two Houses.

item.title: Providing for an adjournment or recess of the two Houses.
Providing for an adjournment or recess of the two Houses.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
